ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BUS SERVICE FOR JALAN BAHAR


    1. Mr Chia Thye Poh asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he is aware that there is no bus route along Jalan Bahar off Jurong Road 13½ milestone and whether a bus service can be authorised to serve that area.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister (Inche Buang Bin Omar Junid) (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the competent authority for the licensing of bus services is the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority. This Authority is established under the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority Ordinance, 1956, and is charged with the function of considering applications from bus companies for licences to operate bus services within the State of Singapore. It has full discretion in granting or refusing to grant a licence in respect of any bus route. In exercising its discretion, it is required under the Ordinance to take into account, among other things, the suitability of the route on which a service is to be provided and the extent to which the proposed services are necessary or desirable in the public interest.

    At present, Jurong Road is served by the Green Bus Co., Ltd. operating from its town terminus at Queen Street, up to the 18th milestone, Jurong. No application has been received by the Omnibus

Column: 512

Services Licensing Authority, from the Green Bus Co., Ltd., or any other bus company for a bus service to be operated along Jalan Bahar, off Jurong Road.

QUARTERS FOR PUBLIC DAILY-RATED EMPLOYEES


    2. Mrs C. V. Devan Nair asked the Minister for Finance (a) whether he is aware of the undertaking given by the Government, contained in a collective agreement with the Public Daily Rated Employees' Unions Federation in 1961, that quarters would be built for public daily-rated employees every year; (b) how many such quarters have been built by the Government over the last two years; and (c) what the Government proposes to do in order to implement the undertaking.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the Government is aware of the undertaking to build quarters for the daily-rated employees. Quarters have been built for the daily-rated employees. For instance, the P.W.D. will complete, towards the end of this year, 30 quarters costing $120,000 for daily-rated employees at Ulu Pandan Sewerage Works. The Minister for Health will construct 20 quarters next year at Choa Chu Kang Burial Grounds. The project costs $89,000. The Government has implemented the undertaking and will continue to implement it.

SCHOOL IN BULIM VILLAGE


    3. Mr Chia Thye Poh asked the Minister for Education whether the Government has any plans to establish a school in Bulim Village at 12 milestone Jurong Road, and what language will be the medium of instruction in this school.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no plan to establish a school at 12 milestone Jurong Road. However, a rural type primary school is being built in Resettlement Area 5A, off 13½ milestone Choa Chu Kang Road, where Bulim Village is situated. This is a 10-classroom school. This school is expected to be ready for occupation at the commencement of the next school year. The media of instruction will be decided

Column: 513

on the basis of actual demand. In view of the large Chinese population here, it is safe to presume that Chinese will be one of the media of instruction.

REPAIR OF TRACKS IN JURONG


    4. Mr Chia Thye Poh asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that the following tracks in the Jurong area are in a state of disrepair and whether he will take steps to have them repaired: (i) Tuas Road; (ii) Track 37 (Lokyang Road); (iii) Track 18.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, (i) a proposal to metal Jalan Tuas has been approved by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee. Metalling of this road from Jurong Road to the Chinese temple will be carried out by the Singapore Work Brigade soon.

    (ii) A proposal to repair Track 37 (Lokyang Road) was considered by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee. The Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee visited Jalan Tuas and Lokyang Road on the 13th of June, 1964, following which proposals for their improvement were approved. Track 37 (Lokyang Road) was repaired and railings were provided at two bridges along the road some time ago.

    (iii) Members of the Citizens Consultative Committee have asked for Track 18, Jurong, to be repaired. A proposal to make up this road to agricultural road standard is being considered by the Urban and Rural Services Consultative Committee.

    Head 0402 -

    Mr Ong Lian Teng (Bukit Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

*The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Lim Huan Boon


    Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not a new issue, it is because the Government has never resolved the problem that it is necessary for me to raise it again in this House today. At present, people who are staying on private land, if they have to remove or to rebuild their houses, are still faced with difficulties. Also it takes a long time for their applications to be considered and approved in order to rebuild their houses. According to my information, there are certain people whose applications have taken six months before they have been looked into by the authorities concerned, thus causing them great inconvenience. Perhaps, this delay has something to do with the relationship between the authorities and the applicants. Perhaps it also has something to do with the landowners concerned.

    At the last Assembly sitting, the Prime Minister, in answer to my question, said that the Government cannot allow people to build chicken runs or pig sties on any piece of ground they like, so as to extend their structures; because when the Government wants them to remove, it will then have to pay more compensation to them.

Column: 515



    It seems that the same principle is applied to applicants who want to extend their houses. In the case of occupiers of houses who are on good terms with the landlord and who have paid him some tea money, they will usually get his permission to extend their houses. But the situation is different with other occupiers. When the landlord refuses their applications, they are faced with great inconvenience and difficulties.

    I have just mentioned that there are certain people who have wanted to apply for an extension of their houses, but their landlord has asked them to apply to the Building Survey Department and the Department has asked the applicants to submit a detailed plan. In certain cases the applications have taken about six months to be considered and approved. I would like to ask the Minister whether it is a good thing for the authorities concerned to delay the approval of such applications.

    Another thing is the alteration of houses. Normally houses have the kitchen separated from the hall and the bedrooms. When the occupiers ask for approval to separate the kitchen from the hall, they have to seek the approval of the landlord concerned. Without their approval, the applicants cannot even apply to the authorities concerned to have such alteration to the house approved.

    Thirdly, about removal from one place to another within the same mukim - not more than 10 feet - the purpose of which is normally to improve the situation of the house.

2.45 p.m.

    Such improvements or alterations to the building structure have also to be approved by the landlord. I hope the Minister can give an explanation to my questions.

    Mr Lim Huan Boon (Bukit Merah): I am not speaking on my amendment.

    The Chairman: Very well. The amendment is now open to debate.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker,

Column: 516

Sir, I would like to assure the Opposition that if there is any application to improve the plan or siting of a house, we will always try to expedite it. The Member's difficulty, as I understand him, is that he feels that landlords are trying to hinder applicants in their requests for permission to repair or enlarge the house. Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we all agree that ownership of land in Singapore confers upon the owner certain rights. Therefore, whether the owner is willing to allow the tenant to extend or repair the house is a matter between him and the tenant. It is something which the Government cannot force the owner to do.

    As regards the Member's allegation that we are always making it difficult for people who want to repair their house, I would like to ask, what are the difficulties which they encounter with the Chief Building Surveyor's Department? Because if the application does come in with the permission of the owner, and if it conforms to building regulations, we will always pass it with as little delay as possible.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to get the understanding of the Minister on this question. When the Government tries to evict farmers, it builds cheap and simple houses for them in order to resettle them. These simple and cheap houses ---

    Mr Lim Kim San: On a point of order. We are debating the Chief Building Surveyor's Department, which has to do with the passing of plans, buildings, and repairs. But the Member for Jalan Kayu is talking about resettlement. I do not think the Chief Building Surveyor's Department covers that at all.

    The Chairman: I was watching the Member. I was thinking that perhaps he was introducing his speech by saying that people who are displaced in those circumstances should possibly be helped by the Chief Building Surveyor's Department. If he proceeds along those lines, he is in order. But if he proceeds on some other line, then he could he completely out of order. I am watching him.

Column: 517



    Mr Lim Kim San: Thank you.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was saying that the Government build cheap and simple houses for the farmers, and whether the farmers can get approval for this type of house from the Building Surveyor's Department. This Department approves certain plans of houses which are a bit complicated and which involve a building cost running into a few thousand dollars. But the houses allotted to the farmers cost only about $1,000 in the resettlement area. I wonder whether the Department concerned can approve the applications by the farmers to build such houses for themselves, and whether the plans for these simple houses can be approved by the Building Surveyor's Department so that the farmers themselves can build the houses on the same lines and pattern.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, in our resettlement programme, we have certain standard houses which cost about $1,000 to build. If it is really required, I see no difficulty in churning out these plans for standard-type houses for farmers if they so wish to build themselves.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I feel that the Minister has not given a full reply to my questions raised just now. The question is not whether the applicants have followed the regulations or not. In fact, they have. There is no ambiguity about that.

    What I am talking about is this: after they have complied with all the regulations and yet are faced with difficulties, the power to approve their applications lies either with the landowners themselves or with the Government.

    The second question is about the alteration to the plans of a house. The Minister has not given a full reply to this question. As regards the conferment of certain rights on the landowners, I do not deny such rights. But the landowners' rights are not absolute. It is not correct to get approval from the landowner whenever a tenant wants to alter his house. If his house is in a poor state, of course, he has to repair it. If the landowners in other areas also

Column: 518

have the same right to deny the tenants' applications for alteration of houses, then they will not be able to find another place for resettlement.

    As regards the extension of houses, there are certain enlightened landowners who demand that if tenants agree to pay a higher rental, then, of course, they will approve. This is also one of the rights of landowners.

    As regards the construction and alteration of houses, if the landowners do not give their approval for them, then what will happen to the tenants?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, just now I have said that the law of the land respects the rights of ownership, and the owner of land has certain rights. One of the rights is that the tenant must get permission from the owner of the land for any alteration or repairs. And if the Member does not like the law, I suggest that he move a motion here to change the law.

    Mr Koo Young (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the issue is very clear. If a tenant rents a piece of land, say, for 30 or 50 years, he may want to repair his house but does not want to extend it; so that it may be in a habitable condition.

    The Chairman: The Member for Bukit Panjang was talking about extensions and alterations, and not repairs.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has just now talked about the reconstruction of houses, and that the right lies with the landowner. If that is the case, then many people will be faced with the problem of not knowing where to live.

    As a democratic socialist Government, they should not ask the Opposition to move a motion to amend the relevant laws. This is irresponsible. What we want is that the P.A.P. should consider their problem of housing in a sympathetic light and should treat this question as a simple issue.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we have in the past treated all what we call unauthorised repairs with sympathy, and we are treating them

Column: 519

with sympathy now. What the Member meant was that normally if a tenant has a broken roof and repairs it, we do not take any action if there is no extension or alteration to the house. I do like him to bring up any case where a tenant with a broken attap roof has repaired it and the Department has taken action against him. I do not remember any case of such a nature at all. We have been most sympathetic wherever we can.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): I want to know whether the landowners have the right to prevent tenants from repairing their houses or reconstructing them.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, I am not a lawyer, otherwise I will quote him chapter and verse and give him a verbatim report.

    But in reply to his question, I would say, yes, the landlord has every right; and the tenant has got to ask his permission for any repairs or alterations under the existing law.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I feel that the reply given by the Minister refers to cases of repair where the landowner has the right to interfere. But if a house is not being extended, but is being repaired only, will the Building Surveyor's Department approve such an application?

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister has said that maybe there were certain houses which were not authorised. I want to know about the case of tenants of houses who want to apply for repairs and who have been paying rent regularly to the landowners. There have been cases of delay of up to six months. This is a very thorny problem. The reply given by the Minister does not seem to solve this problem.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Regarding the repair and extension of houses, if a house is in a state of disrepair and cannot be habitable any more, then the tenant should negotiate with the landowner. There is a form in the Building Survey Department which provides

Column: 520

that the landowner can approve by putting his signature. But the plan of such a house should be submitted to the Building Survey Department. After receiving this form, the Building Survey Department will despatch an inspector there to investigate. Once it is approved, the tenant concerned can carry out his repair and this repair should be in accordance with the plans submitted.

    The Opposition Party exaggerates by saying that there has been a delay of up to six months. For the past few days, they have been telling falsehoods. For example, they have said that the Government has forced farmers to live in Housing Board flats. All these accusations are groundless. This is only one example of their falsehoods which they have uttered in this House.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): I feel that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development is not being responsible. He says that we have exaggerated by saying that there have been certain cases of delay of up to six months. I am speaking from actual facts. If the Parliamentary Secretary does not believe me, he can refer to his files in his office. He will then understand. Maybe he has not referred to his files. That is why he has accused us of having exaggerated the case.

    The Chairman: Let us go on to the subject in question. Let us not get to the files or indulge in personal accusations. Let us try to get on to repairs, alterations and additions.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to what the Member for Bukit Panjang has said about the six months' delay, I have just now said that the best thing for him to do is to give us concrete examples, so that we can study and investigate them. I would also like to point out another thing. In case of such delay, it might well be that the applicant has not submitted the plan which is necessary to the Building Survey Department, and perhaps the landlord has not approved the application by countersigning the form. Thus the delay has been caused by this. If the applicant does not produce the plan for repairs at the time,

Column: 521

of course, there will be a delay in the approval.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): The Parliamentary Secretary has once again asked me to give a concrete example. I have already replied to him by asking him to look into his own files and see whether there is such a case of an applicant who has submitted his application and for six months nothing has been done. There is one by the name of Mr Ho Pak Toh. Up to now, his application has not been approved, and during this time there have already been two changes in the head of the Building Survey Department. The Parliamentary Secretary should refer to his files and should not accuse me of uttering falsehoods.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: I would like the Opposition Member to single out one case. What is the house number and where is it situated? I can then find out all the facts for him and what is wrong about the case.

    The Chairman: That seems to me to be a very fair request.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): If the Parliamentary Secretary wants an example, he is sure to find it in the file. I will let him know the name of the area in which this incident happened. I am afraid I cannot remember the number of the house. The applicant is living at Bukit Panjang, 10 milestone. The name of the street is Jalan Kon Kuan. The name of the applicant is Yang Lian Seng. If he wants to refer to the file now, he can easily do so. There is such an incident.

    Mr Lim Kim San: We have thousands of files in the Chief Building Survey Department. If the Member is really interested in this particular case, I am also interested in it, because if he had seen the Chief Building Surveyor three times and no satisfactory explanation was given to him as to why it took more than six months to get a plan approved, then I am interested in the case myself. Therefore, if he can give me the number of the application, that is the only way we can find out. From the number of the application we can

Column: 522

trace the applicant, and I will be very interested to find out why it took such a long time. There must be very good reasons. As it is, the Member for Jalan Kayu just says that there is a delay. If he had seen the C.B.S. three times, I think the C.B.S. must have explained to him why the delay occurred.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, what I am concerned with is not this particular case. What I am concerned with is the policy of the Government. Is it not the policy of the Government to afford convenience to the people? If the Government is concerned with the interest of the landlords, the problem would be whether it has made provisions to rebuild without the approval of the landlord. If the Government does not protect the people, then they will not be able to rebuild their houses. The Minister says that the landowner has to sign the application first. But if the landlord does not want to sign, what will happen? There will be a lot of difficulties. If such things continue, then conditions will become worse. The houses will collapse. We have seen with our eyes houses collapsing. We would like the Government to amend the law to enable the people to rebuild with convenience.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was an allegation that the Government has delayed for six months, or more than six months, and that they have difficulty with the C.B.S. But when we asked for a specific instance, it was not forthcoming.

    With regard to the Member's other point, I have been trying to explain that the landlord has certain rights of ownership. I think it is the same law almost thoughout the world. I do not see how we can change it so that any Tom, Dick and Harry who wants to have a house built on anybody's land can just send in an application without getting permission from the landlord. I do not think there is any law anywhere of that nature.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng(In Mandarin): I would like to have a vote.

    Head 0403 -

*The same amendment also stood in the name if Mr Koo Young.


    At the time when the Housing and Development (Amendment) Bill was passed, the Minister concerned said that the Government intended to reconsider the Master Plan and re-delineate the plan, and to start with the development of the rural areas and to rebuild the city. The legislation that has been passed seems to give the Minister too extensive powers, because he can decide at his discretion which area should be developed.

    The Chairman: The Member is out of order. He can use the provisions of that Bill to base his speech on, but he may not criticise the provisions of that Bill or the passing of that Bill.

    Mr Lim Huan Boon(In Mandarin): Yes. Mr Speaker, Sir. The Minister can, at his own discretion, decide whether certain areas should be developed or not. I would like to ask him what criterion is applied when he decides which area should be developed or which area should not be developed. I raise this question not because I do not have confidence in him. What I am concerned with is that there may be landlords who may want to make use of any possible chances to achieve their own personal ends. That is why I now wish to stress that if any site is to be developed, there should be a certain suitable criterion. It should be according to stipulated conditions. Otherwise, there will be cause for ill-feelings and sentiments. That is why I am putting forward my suggestion under this Head.

Column: 524



3.15 p.m.

    Certainly the Government should - and I stress the word "should" - control land prices. There should also be a fair and just standard, otherwise the green belt areas after development will become developed areas and the price of land will increase. Superficially, the rural areas may look developed. There are skyscrapers everywhere, but the houses are at prices that cannot be bought by the people. The people have lost their land to the landlords as a result of which they are faced with great difficulties in earning their livelihood. Undoubtedly the consequences will be construed to mean that the Government is benefiting from the landlords; this runs contrary to socialist principles.

    The green belt areas are mostly areas where the poorer people live. Every year, they have to pay rentals, and after certain expenses they can start their agricultural activities and build their huts and homes on the sites to maintain themselves. But once these green belt areas are developed, then these people will meet with difficulties. Even if they want to take up residence in cheap Government flats, they will find it difficult to do so, because there are considerations like making their living. Therefore, before the Minister decides on the green belts to be developed, he should take proper steps to consult the people concerned and ensure the protection of their livelihood, otherwise the superficial development and prosperity will not be in keeping with socialist principles.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, this Government has the interest of every section of the public at heart. We see to it that in our efforts to bring about a more democratic and prosperous society in any development programme, no section of the public suffers.

    I can assure the Member for Bukit Merah that the last thing I want to see is the private developers making large sums of money out of our development. I think he is quite aware that we did introduce the Planning (Amendment)

Column: 525

Bill where development charges will be levied on private developers. This is just to ensure that whatever profit the developers may make, a part of it will be returned to the public through development charges.

    I am thankful that the hon. Member has said that he has confidence in me, and I can assure him that his confidence will not be misplaced, because I am not the only one who decides whether an area should be developed or not; it is decided by a team of experts - experts in traffic and experts in planning - and all of them are technicians who are able to plan for the increase in population that we envisage in 1990. Before we decide whether a green belt should remain so or whether there should be a change of use, the effect that the precinctal development aspects will have on our livelihood, traffic problem and total development will be taken into consideration. So I do not think that the decision to change the use of any place will depend on the decision of one man. It will have to be thoroughly discussed by a team of experts. Moreover, when the Master Plan is revised - and it will be revised at the beginning of next year - representations from the public will be received before it is finally approved. Therefore, on that score, I think the hon. Member can set his qualms at rest. It is not the decision of one man, and therefore he cannot be influenced or bought over by any large land-owner.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the aim of this Government to raise the standard of living of our people. I will say that we will have succeeded to some extent if we can plan our industrialisation so that the present so-called farmers who are eking out a living from the land will be able to change to a new way of life which will give him a better return. I am sure hon. Members opposite will not like to see the same living conditions under which the farmers are eking out a living in the open green space to continue. I think they will like to see that the farmers have a higher standard of living. As it is now, seeing the way they are living in spite

Column: 526

of our efforts to increase production by expert advice from the Primary Production Department, I do not think that their standard of living is something which we should allow to continue.
